To se you demeaned that wyse
I trow ye be set all on couetyse

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Cou •… tyse / nay let be
It ys a thyng of greter cure
That stycketh in my mynde be thou sure

sp.speaker: slouth.
sp.l: ¶ So me thought by the rode
I wyst as myche there was som thyng
By your •… o wryng chere and your syghyng
That was not all thyng good
But what ys the mater I pray you hartely

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ I wys thou canst not deuyse the remedy
wyth all the wyt thou hast
But thys ys the case to tell yt shortely
A thyng was told me as I cam hereby
Now Reason puruayth fast
And maketh very great labour and ordynaunce
To dashe vs all out of countenaunce
And for that purpose
He hath gadred a great cumpany

sp.speaker: slouth.
sp.l: ¶ What to do
¶ I wore nere I
But as I suppose
It ys to bryng me in captyuyte
And to take frome my l •… berte
So he hath oft sayd

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ •… ere ye that mater

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Nay neuer a dell
but I care for yt wyt ye well
Yet am I not afrayd
For I wyst wythstand yt proudly
and syrs I trust ye wyll stand therby
whan yt shalbe nede

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ ye by the way that god went
Or he haue of you hys intent
Fyrst shall I blede
The best blode that ys in thys carcas

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Well ease go thy way hens a pace
and make therin good spede
Call my cumpany all togeder
and byd theym euery man com heder
That ys wyth me affeed

sp.speaker: slouth.
sp.l: ¶ Mary syr that shalbe do

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Wurshyp in the mean tyme let vs go
To se my new apparell

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ Wyll ye so. Now for your ladyes sake
Go do yt on you and I vndertake
It shall becom you well

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Worldly affeccy on abyde thou here
For I wyll go do on thys new gere
as wurshyp doth me counsell
sp.stage: ¶ Then Man and Pryde goeth out.

sp.speaker: w. aff.
sp.l: ¶ Mary I shall wyth all myne hart
thys good fyre and I wyll nor depart
For very cold myne hand ys do smart
It maketh me wo bygon
Get me a s •… ole here may ye not se
Or e •… ys a chayr wyll yt not be
thou pyld knaue I speke to the
Now •… ong shall I stande

sp.speaker: ¶ Glotony.
sp.l: ¶ •… et hym stand wyth a foule euyll
〈◊〉 ye se so / euery dr •… uyll
Now adayes I w •… rand
Must commaund as he were a kyng
Let hym stande on hys sete wyth bredyng

sp.speaker: w. aff.
sp.l: ¶ What Glotony / I can tell the one thyng
In fa •… th you wyll be shent

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ Why

sp.speaker: w. aff.
sp.l: ¶ My mayster hath sent Sensualyte
To seke the all about the contre
Spakest thou not wyth hym

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ yes parde
I know all hys intent
And thereuppon I am com here
For to awa •… t / but wotest thou where
Our mayster ys now

sp.speaker: w. aff.
sp.l: ¶ Nay I wote nere
I am not very certayn
But Pryde and he together begon
Ne sayd he wold com agayn anon
wythin an howr or twayn
Tary thou here and go net away
I wyll go breke my fast and I may
For I ete neuer a morsell thys day

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ Mary that ys a thyng
Go whan thou wyst I wyll abyde
My stomak he shall not rule or gyde
That ys now fastyng
Nay of all thynge erthly I hate to fast
Four tymes a day I make repast
Or thryse as I suppose
And whan I am well fed
Than get I me to a soft bed
my body to repose
There take I a nap or twayn
•… p I go streyght and to yt agayn
Though nature be net redy
yet haue I some mete of delyte
For to prouoke •… happetyte
And make the stomak gredy
After all thys nedys I must
Somtyme folow the wanton lust
For hote drynkys and delycate reflecyon
Causeth flesshely insurreccyon
ye know yt as well as I

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Trouth as ye say I know yt well

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ What gentylman ys thys can ye tell

sp.speaker: bodyly.
sp.l: ¶ Wotyst thou neuer

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ No by the bell
I saw hym neuer byfore

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ Is yt our mayster

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ Nay by the rood
It ys not he woldyst thou make me wood

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ yes I am the same

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ I cry you mercy I se yt well now
Byfore I knew you not I make god auow
In ernest nor in game

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Why. Bycause I haue chaunged myne aray

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ For that cause trow ye nay nay
That ys not the thyng
That can dysceyue me be ye sure
but I pray you who hath had you in cure
Syth my last departyng

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ By my fayth a lytell season
I folowed the counsell and dyet of reason

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ There went the hare away
Hys dyet ꝙ a / yt may be veryly
For ye be haltred maruelously
Altred I wold say
alas the whyle had ye no mete
As long as ye were vnder hys dyet

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Mete / yes I had som
wythout yt were on fastyng dayes
Than he wythdrew my supper alwayes
and gaue me neuer a crom

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ No force hardely why wold ye than
fauor hym as ye dyd lyke a madman
ye loke now as yt were a gost
Had ye dwelt wyth hym tyll thys day
ye had bene pyned euen away
as ye be now almost
your fleshe ys gon euery dell
A vengeaunce on the morsell
That ys left theron

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ Now talk of the remedy

sp.speaker: gsoto.
sp.l: ¶ 〈◊〉 now 〈◊〉 the 〈◊〉 and 〈◊〉 safe
〈◊◊〉 ye there none

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ ye bu •… where ye the m •… te now 〈◊◊〉

sp.speaker: gsoto.
sp.l: ¶ ye are •… yng hasty be ne d •…
frist must ye go
where as prouer spon therof ye made
Let ve go thyder and re shalbe had

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ But what to the marsiers of the in
A weddyd woman or a vyrgyn

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ Nerther of both I ioys

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: 〈◊〉 No / but for a mayden she goth

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ ye forgod that she doth
But yet she ye none by Iye

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ No / no / what than

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ I wye I not / but as men clater
They say she ye innupta mater
Hardely an holy woman

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Well thyder we wyll / go we hens

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ Syr ye wyll gyue me lycence
To sport me for a season

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ yes for a whyle ye well I now
but go not out of the way I charge you
for hyder wyll come anone
All my cumpany as I suppose
Kepe theym together for I purpose
to come agayn anone
and shew theym my mynde what I wyll do

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ Mary I shall do what I can thereto
and yet yt ye hard for me
to kepe theym together any whyle
But I shall tell you what
I had seuer kepe as many flese
Or wyld hares in an opyn lese
as vndertake that

sp.speaker: ¶ Wrath.
sp.l: ¶ Wherebe these knaues that make thys aray

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ Mary they be gon that other way
tell me whome ye meane

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶ I trow thou scornyst

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ Nay certaynly
How so be yt yf I shuld not ly
at the fyrst blushe I ensure you faythfully
I f •… nd forgot you 〈◊〉
〈◊〉 ye be thus defensybly arayd
〈◊〉 at that are ye affrayd
who fiath you greued

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶ Nay I fere no man that bereth an hee
〈◊〉 I seuer that I were dede
than that shuld be preued

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ By my fayth ye are wont to be as bold
as yt were a lyon of cottyswold
but now to my questyon
what meaneth all thys defensyble aray

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶ Mary slouth warned vs two thys same day
Euen syth yt was none
that our moyster and Reason shuld make a stay
and therfore he had vs wythout delay
to awayt on our capytayn

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ A now I know the mater ryght well
But what shall com therof I can not tell
It passeth my brayn
Our mayster wylled that we twayn
Shuld tary here tyll he com agayn

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ What wylt thou do than

sp.speaker: bodyly
sp.l: ¶ Who I Ienay care not for me
I wyll not com where strokys be
I am not so mad a man
And I wys yt ys not for any fere
But yt ys a thyng that I can well forbere
And wyll as long as I can
Of lust and pleasure ys all my mynde
It longeth to me of properte and kynde
And yf I shuld to the warre
And ly in myne harnes as other men do
•… yth hunger and thurst a day or two
It shuld me vtterly marre

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ It were a great losse yf thou were mard
Now fy on the stath horson coward
By cokkys preciouse blode
It were no syn to sle suche a knaue
Host not thou wagys as other men haue
And few of vs so good
yet wylt thou fayll vs at thys nede
Now who so euer shall quyte my mede
〈◊〉 wyll no further go
〈◊〉 I haue 〈◊◊〉 myne own hand
〈◊◊〉 I sh •… d 〈◊〉 were the land
Euen when I haue do
〈◊◊◊〉 I you re quy •… e
〈◊〉 as wo •… ye not at my desyre
Do so my •… e for me
I 〈◊〉 wold haue done me more good
to haue s •… ne the knaues hart blode
than. xx. shrll •… ngys of fee

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ What how syrs what meaneth thys gere,
wyll ye sle eche other here
No more of thys worke

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ By the hart of god and he had abyden
A lytell whyle he shuld neuer haue spoken
wyth preste nor wyth clarke

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Who was that

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ your own mynyon
Bodyly lust

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Why what hath he done

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Euen like a lurden
He sayth that ye haue gyuen hym lycence,
to abyde at home and kepe resydence
whyle we bere the burden
And serue you now at your nede

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ He prayde me so in very dede
wythin these. ii. dayes
He sayd he wold serue me wyth a good wyll
But of the warrys he could no skyll
Nor knew therof the wayes
How be yt I gaue hym therof none answere

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ No but I am sure he wyll not com there
And now ma •… ye se
That no man ys so myche to blame
As your selfe

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ I

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ ye by saynt I ame
No man but euen ye
for I am well a Jured of one thyng
ye gaue hym better clothyng
Than ye dyd me
And better wagys and fees also
And though I sayd but lytell thereto
But suffered euer more
yet I by •… aynd yt euer in my mynde
And though that ye were to me vnkynde
To set so 〈◊〉 at store
By suche a knaue as he was
I wold I had hym here by the masse
And no man but we twayn

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ By my trouth thys ys euer thy guyse
Ioke by whom I set any pryse
Hym thou wylt most dysoayn

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶ By cryst he can do none other wyse
but now syr ys there any seruyce
That ye wyll commaunde me

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ ye mary ys there / but my cumpany
Dresseth theym forward passyng slowly
I trow yt wyll not be
Manhode thou art good I now for one

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶ ye by cryst and they cam euery chone
I wyll not gretly fere

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ By my trouth bycause he sayth so
I shall tell you what I saw hym do
I was present there
Syr yt happyned in westmynster hall
Euen byfore the Iuges all
Hys handys were bound fast
And neuer vpon hym that euer god made
Dager sword nor knyfe he had
And yet at the last
He draue. xii. men into a corner
and an howi after durst they not appere
How say ye hereto
and hys handys had bene at syberte
He wose haue put theym in great I eoparde
It ys to suppose so

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Mary there he qurte hym well
but where be myne other folk can ye tell
¶ Thē cometh i Glotony wyth a chese i a botell.

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶ Mary here cometh one
Good felyshyp me semeth yt shuld be

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ Syrs god spede you

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ What tydyngys wyth the

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶ I shall tell you anone
For •… o a •… de vppon 〈◊〉

〈◊〉
•… ll a warfare 〈◊◊〉 me

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: •… re •… s •… es I now

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶Why hast thou no •… e 〈◊◊〉 but thys

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶What the deuyll harnes shuld I mys
wythout yt be a botell
Another botell I wyll go puruey
Lest that drynk be scarce in the way
Or happely none to sell

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶Thou must haue other harnes than thys man

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶Other harnes nay I shrew me than
I can no skyll theron
why trowest thou that I wyll fyght

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ye so I trow

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶Nay by god almyght
Therof wyll I none
I was neuer wont to that gere
But I may serue to be a vyteler
And therof shall ye haue store
So that I may stand out of daunger
Ofgon shot / but I wyll com no nere
I warn you that byfore

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶Now suche a knaue I betake to the deuyll
Thys ys euen suche a nother dreuyll
As was here whyle ere
They be. ii. knaues annoynted
I fere me syr ye shalbe dysappoynted
I syke not thys gere

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶O I had for goten I make god auow
Syr my felow ease commaundeth me to you

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶Commaundeth the to me

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶you to me

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶Me to the

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶Commaundeth you to hym I wold haue sayd

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶Why cometh he not hyder

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶By god for he ys afrayd
And lyeth syk in hys bed
He toke such a consext whan he hard of thys gere
That for thought and very fere

sp.speaker: wrath.
sp.l: ¶And he were hanged yt were no 〈◊〉
I p •… ay god the deuyll breke hys ne •…
and all suche as he ys

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶Well l •… t vs suffer for a whyle
I wyll go walke hens halfe a myle
and for all thys
Happely all thys gere shall not nede
Now be yt that I dout and drede
The wurst as wyse men do
Manhode com thy selfe wyth me

sp.speaker: gloto.
sp.l: ¶And I to syr

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ye parde
woldyst thou be prayd thereto

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶Now he that wold haue warre or stryfe
I pray god send hym a shrewd wyfe
and than shall he haue I now
But I shall tell you syrs as for me
I am none of theym so mot I the
I may say to you
I wyll no suche rekennyng ys abyde
Goddys body here cometh Pryde
as crank as a pecok
As sone as he and I mete
wythout he stand ryght vppon hys fete
He shall bere me a proude mok

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶What tydyngys syrs can any man tell

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ye mary that can I do as well
as any that was in feld
ye haue taryed so long about your gay gere
That the feld ys done or ye come there

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶Done mary god sheld

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶It ys done wythout fayll
But whyehe of theym hath wone the balayll
I can not tell you certayn

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶Thou were not there yt semeth therby

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶Not I there ꝙ ayes hardely / 〈◊〉 that to my grete
but as sone as ye batellys ioyned togeder (payn
I cam my way streyght heder / for to tell tydyng •…

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶What the deuyll tydyngys canst thou tell

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶Mary I can shew you nothyng of the batell
but of ma •… y other tydyngys
ye are out of concext I tell you foreuer
B •… cause 〈◊〉 not you endeuou •…
•… t th •… s great 〈◊〉
I •… so m •… e 〈◊〉 ye ore 〈◊〉 to sees
•… eth 〈◊〉 off •… ce and all your fees
And 〈◊〉 out of wa •… s

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ That ys not true as I suppose

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Syr and •… t be not t •… ke my nose
And my hed also
your offyce was gyuen or I cam thens

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ Mary that was a very short sentence
and I not cassed therto
Now enuy what counsell wyst thou gyue me

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ By my trouth Pryde thou mayst byleue me
I •… I were in thy case
I wold wythdrawe me for a season
though yt be nother felony nor treason
Nor yet wylfull tre space
yet the same ys wurst of all
For euery knaue wyll the call
a co ward to thy face

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ I am vnhappy I seyt well
for thexpense of myne apparell
towardys this vyage
what in horses and other aray
•… ath compessed me for to say
all my sand to morgage
and now whan I haue all do
To lesse myne offyce and fees also
For my true intent
I may say that all my cost
and all my tyme ys euyll lost
In seruyce that I haue spent
well what so euer by tyde me
for a season I wyll hyde me
after thy counsell
and syth yt wyll no better be
Fare well I take my seue of the

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ •… ow gentyll Pryde fare well
Alas that I had no good felow here
to bere me cumpany and laugh at thys gere
thys game was well founde

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ yes and ye lust to play the knaue
Some maner of cumpany ye myght haue
S •… e wythin thys grounde

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Some I can thynke y •… ng or old
And 〈◊〉 yt were a small houshold
as any myght be found

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ It ys not small the company sheweth well
But me thought thou were about to tell
Of some mery I este
Or som mery game at my cummyng

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ ye fardely yt ys a game for a hyng
whan he lusteth best
To laugh for hys dysporte and solace
Syr I shall tell the thys ys the case
Ryght now as I stode
In thys place and neuer a man wyth me
In cam Pryde garnyshed as yt had be
One of the ryall blode
It greued me to se hym so well be sene
But I haue abated hys corage clene
For a lytell season
By the rode I haue gyuen hym a chek mate
For I bare hym an hand that he cam to fate
And that the feld was done
and how hys offyce was gyuen away
Bycause he fayled our mayster that day
I made hym to byleue so
And whan I had told hym all thys tale
anone he began to wax all pale
Full of care and wo
and now he hydeth hym felfe for shame
I gaue hym myne aduyse to the same
and so he ys gon

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ Now on my fayth thys was madly do
but in fayth what moueth the therto

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Mary cause had I none
but only that yt ys my guyse
Whan I se another man aryse
Or fare better than I
Than must I chafe and fret for yre
and ymagyn wyth all my desyre
To dystroy hym vtterly
But now in ernest Sensualyte
tell me whan thys fray shal be
I pray ye hartely. ¶ Sensua. What agaynst Rea.
¶ •… e the same

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ 〈◊〉 they be agreed in yarn of shame
and go •… d cumpany they kepe

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Agreed 〈◊〉 in the m •… re name
Mary fyr •… at were a game
to make some of vs wepe

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ We •… e or laugh man so yt ys
and who trow ye ys the •… a user of thys

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Who

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ Age the deuyll hym quell

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Why ys age now com in pl •… ce

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ ye and that may ye spy by hys face
and ye mark yt well
Hys stomak faynteth euery day
Hys bak croketh hys hed waxeth gray
Hys nose droppeth among
Hys lust ys gone and all hys lykyng
I se yt well by euery thyng
He may not lyue long
and all maketh age as I sayd byfore
He ys the dear / and what trow ye more
thys age hath done

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ What

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ By my fayth he hath brought in Reason
In suche wyse that at no season
Nothyng can be wrought
B •… t Reason must be called therto
I fere me he wyll vs all vndo
wythin few dayes
As sone as Glotony had espyde
all thys gere he wold not abyde
but went euen hys wayes
Our mayster prayed hym to t •… ry a season
Nay nay quod he / now haue I done
I may no lengar tary
For age and I may not togeder dwell
and streyght way he departed fayre and well
Bodyly lust stode by
and saw that Glotony wold nedys be gon
•… aue wyth the Glotony quod he anon
For I must go wyth the
So that. 〈◊〉 . be gon togeder
〈◊〉 am there none of theym both heder

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Neuer a one that I se

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ Well they be gon some other way
to get a new mayster as sone as they may
They can not be ou • urueyd
and as for • as they. ii. were gon
Our mayster sent for couetyse anon
and •• rtesy hym prayd
to awayt on hym well for a yere or two
and he hath promysed hym so to do
as for a yere or twayn
But Reason may not therof know

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ Reason quod a / no so I trow
He wyll that dysdayn
but where hath couetyse ben many a day

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ He dwelled wyth a prest as I herd say
For he loueth well
Men of the chyrche / and they hym also
and lawyars the / whan they may tend therto
wyll folow hys counsell

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ So men say these as I dwell
but Sensualyte canst thou tell
Now in thys case
what were best for vs to do

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ Mary I hold yt best that we go
Nere by to som place
and semble togeder all our cumpany
to here there myndys by and by
and euery mannys opynyon
what shalbe best for to do

sp.speaker: enuy.
sp.l: ¶ By my trouth and be yt so
I hold yt welldon
sp.stage: ¶ Than they go forth & Reason & Man com in.

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: ¶ Syr I haue oft tymes you aduysed
to lyue vertuously / and shewd you the way
and that not wythstandyng / ye haue me dyspysed
And folowed Sensualyte / meny a day
wyll ye so contynue / ye or nay
If euer ye purpose your selfe to amend
It ys tyme / for your lyfe draweth fast to thend

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ I can not contynue / though I wold
For age hath wayned me clene therfro
and yet Reason / whan ye me told
Of thys gere meny day a go
I 〈◊◊〉 / I shuld 〈◊◊◊〉
〈◊〉 of your wordys / great story and d •…
Wold god that my lyfe were to bygyn agayn

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: ¶ S • eke not therof / that may not be
a thyng don / can not be called agayn
but the thyng / that most fereth me
On your behalue / I tell you playn
Is that ye wold / in no wyse abstayn
From synfull lustys / as I wylled you to do
Tyll now that age compelleth you therto

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ That ys full trew / wrthout faynyng
as long as myne appetyte dyd endure
I folowed my lustys / in euery thyng
whyche now by the course and law of nature
And not of my polycy / or good endeuoure
Is taken fro me / for euer more
And so can I deserue / no mede therfore
¶ But not wythstandyng thys myne abusyon
I trust that by the help of your good aduyse
I may be made the chyld of saluacyon

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: ¶ yes and ye wyll syr on warantyse
So that ye vtterly forsake and dyspyse
All your old seruauntys in wyll and dede
and do by my counsell

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ yes haue ye no drede

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: ¶ Than my soule for yours / I lay to wed
ye shall do well / haue ye no mystrust
And fyrst to begyn wyth / I you forbed
All maner of dyspeyre / and secundly ye must
Put to your mynd / and good wyll
To be recured / of your great excesse
For wythout your helpe / yt can not be doubtles
¶ Is in thys example / yf so be the pacyent
Of hym selfe / be wyllyng to haue any remedy
It ys a great furtheraunce to that intent
So that to the preceptys of physyk he apply
And who so doth the contrary / no maruarll truely
Though he myskary / what shuld I bryng
Any mo examples for so playn a thyng

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ It shalbe no nede as in thys case
I know ryght well / what ye meane therby
And that wyll I folow by godds grace

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: ¶ Than as I told you / yt shalbe no maystry
your selfe confort / and •… o •… aue good remedy

〈◊〉
•… st the great 〈◊〉 that thou hast don
〈◊〉 why the thou hast deserued endles dam •… o •…
¶ •… ut do 〈◊〉 I 〈◊◊〉 the / and •… aue no d •… de
And for to 〈◊〉 the medyeyns / most •… yng
〈◊〉 thy force / do by mr rede
Loke what dysease / •… s 〈◊〉 and b •…
take euer suche a medyeyn as ys 〈◊〉 in w •… yng
So that the contrary in all maner of wrse
Must hele hys contrary as physyh doth deuyse
¶ Ryght so who so lusteth fro syn to aryse
where he hath in pryde / done any offence
He can be helpen therof none other wyse
but onely by mekenes / that ys the recompence
agayn Wreth and Enuy / take charyte and pacyence
take almes dede / agayn the syn of coue •… rse
¶ And to represse glotyny / acquaynt ye wyth abstynece
Agayn foull lust of body / take chastrte 〈◊〉 cōtynēce
Myche syn groweth by Slouth and by Idelnes
and that must be eschewed by mene of good besynes
•… o thys be preparatyfys most souerayn
Agaynst thy sores whyche be mortall
Onles that thys medyeyns to theym be layn
Whan thou hast receyued these preparatyfys all
I wyll com agayn yf thou me call
And order the further after my mynde

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 ye but where shall I these preparatyfys fynde

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: ¶ Thou shalt theym fynde wythm thyn own brest
Of the yt must com / yt must be thy dede
For voluntary sacrafyce pleaseth god best
Thou canst not therof haue help or mede
But yf thys gere of thyn own hart procede

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Well I shall endeuoure me to the vttermost
And trll I haue found theym I shall neuer rest
But how shall I know theym that wote I nere
I pray you shew me that byfore yout departyng

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: ¶ It nedeth not therof to enquere
Thou shalt know theym at the fyrst me •… yng
Of. 〈◊〉 . contrarys there ys but one seruyng
That ys to say whan thou knowyst well that o •…
The other contrary ys knowen anon
sp.stage:
¶ Then he goeth out 〈◊〉
•… kenes cometh in.
sp.l: ¶ Who so woteth hystoryes / of scrypture well
for your 〈◊◊◊〉
It forteth not thou •… ye do

When ye 〈◊〉
•… aue 〈◊〉 for there •… o
And among I wrll helpe you also
In due t •… e and place

sp.speaker: ye wor.
sp.l: ¶ ye that ye wrll in dede
But now •… ye wyll ye any thyng
Com •… nd me byfore mr •… yng

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Nothyng at all to my w •… tyng
But our lord haue you in hys kypyng
And send rou well to spede

sp.speaker: ye wor.
sp.l: ¶ Wo •… dly affeccyon come hyder / ye are polytyke
and myche better enured / in thys world than I
I pray you dyspose for me / as ye thynk most lyke
That I may lyue here well and honorably

sp.speaker: ye wor.
sp.l: ¶ ye s •… I shall. Dout ye not hardely
yf yt lyke you / to put me in so great trust
And I trew ye shall fynde me / trew and iust

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ I wote well I shall. Surely you be bound
To the world / that hath gyuen you so great cōmendacy •…

sp.speaker: ye wor.
sp.l: ¶ ye syr some men had leuer than a thowsand pound
They myght be commended / of the same fassyon
But syr let passe / all thys commendacyon
and answere to me / I pray you frutefully
In that I shall meue you / substancyally
¶ Syr at few wordys / I you exhorte
Syth that ye be come to your own
Cast your selfe to bere suche a porte
That as ye be / ye may be knowen
Eke yt ys necessary / for that behoue
that there be made / some maner of puruyaunce
Wherby / ye may vere out your countenaunce
¶ Wyll yt lyke you therfore / that I suruey
And se thex •… ent'of all your land
and there vppon / in all the hast puruey
Both for rou and yours / all maner of v •… nd
wyth other vtensy •… tys / redy at your hand
So that ye be puruerd / all tymes •… rely and late
Of eche thyng / that belongeth to your estate

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ your counsell ys good / do as ye thynk best
I comm •… t all suche thyng / to your dyscrecyon
¶ I shall do my •… ew / bysynes at the lest
To bryng all thyngys / to good conclusyon

〈◊◊◊◊◊〉
•… yll fyrst 〈◊〉
And other thyn •… rs more tha •… thys
I shall bryng that hart of •… ys
To be more howt than yt ys
•… y a de wys a •… e
•… crally I wyll commend hys wyt
That no man can amend yt
And that he ys able therby to syt
as a iuge in comen place
And when I prayse hym thys wyse
I thynke hys hart wyll begyn to ryse
and after that vtterly despyse
any opray counsell to here
He shall trust all to hys own brayne
and than wold Reason neuer so fayne
Though he come and suche oprytway •…
He shalbe neuer the nere

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ Surely thys conseyt ys well found
I shall bryng the in seruyce fortwaynty pound

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ Gramercy brother I thynk me mych bound
To the forthy curtesy
But syr abyde here on thyng
I wyll not be knowen that yt ys my sekyng

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ No more wold I for. 〈◊〉 . shelyng
Let me alone hardely

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ Sy •… yf yt •… ase yo here ys come a straunge •…
Th •… neuer was aquaynted wyth you ere
Somwhat 〈◊〉 fast and halfe in fere
To put hym selfe in prese
A goodly parsone be ye sure
Both of countenaunce and of feature
If he w •… drawn in portrayture
And a good man doubtles
ye and a wyse man at all
Wyll yt please you that I hym call
to suche wyth you.

sp.speaker: ¶ Mā.
sp.l: byd hym com.

sp.speaker: ¶ Sē.
sp.l: I shall
〈◊〉 wyll ne come nere.

sp.speaker: sensua
sp.l: ¶ 〈◊〉 dyd hym welcome for the maner sake
〈◊◊〉 day I am sure he wyll crake
And 〈◊〉 suche a gentylman dyd hym make
〈◊〉 gr •… at chere
〈◊◊〉 for to dwell wyth you
〈◊〉 you he ys a man for your prow
And knoweth the world well I now
No man better than he

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 Syr ye be welcom to thys place

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ I thanke you syr / but I do you trespace
to come thus homly.

sp.speaker: ¶ Sensua.
sp.l: ye a parlous case
•… d w •… te ye are welcom heder
•… n my fayth by my wyll
ye shall dwell wyth vs styll
Go nere to hym and talk your fyll
I leue you togeder

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Now syr what haue ye to say to me

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ No great thyng syr / but I come to se
And to know what maner man ye be
That all men prayseth so mouche

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Prayse whom prayse they.

sp.speaker: ¶ Pryde.
sp.l: Mary you
Man me.

sp.speaker: ¶ Pryde.
sp.l: ye syr I make myne auow
They gyue you a praysyng good I now
I harde neuer none suche
and surely ye be ryght wurthy
I se well now they do not ly
and therefore I dyd my hyderhy
To acquaym me wyth you
But ye may say that I am bold

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Nay ye ar worth thy weyght of gold
Me thenketh me to you myche behold
I pray you what ys your name

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ My name ys wurshyp.

sp.speaker: ¶ Man.
sp.l: Wurshpp now surely
The world told me yt was my destyny
To come to wurshyp or I dye

sp.speaker: Pryde
sp.l: ¶ Truly I am the same

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: ¶ Now wurshyp I pray you me tell
your wysedom and also counsell
ye can aduertyse me passyng well
In thyngys that I haue to do
